factoid: Rostóv hurriedly put something on his feet.
Rostóv drew on his dressing gown.
Rostóv went out.
Natásha had put on one spurred boot.
Natásha was just getting her foot into the other boot.
Sónya came in.
Sónya was twirling round.
Sónya was about to expand her dresses into a balloon.
Sónya was about to sit down.
Rostóv was dressed in a new pale-blue frock.
Natásha was dressed in a new pale-blue frock.
Rostóv was fresh, rosy, and bright.
Natásha was fresh, rosy, and bright.
Sónya ran away.
Natásha took Rostóv's arm.
Natásha led Rostóv into the sitting room.
Natásha and Rostóv began talking.
Natásha and Rostóv hardly gave each other time to ask questions.
Natásha and Rostóv hardly gave each other time to give replies.
Natásha and Rostóv discussed a thousand little matters.
The matters discussed could not interest anyone but Natásha and Rostóv.
Natásha laughed at every word Rostóv said.
Natásha laughed at every word she said herself.
Natásha laughed because she felt happy.
Natásha was unable to control her joy.
Natásha's joy expressed itself by laughter.
Natásha said "Oh, how nice, how splendid!" to everything.
Rostóv felt that the warm rays of love influenced him.
Rostóv had a childlike smile that had not appeared on his face since he left home.
The childlike smile brightened Rostóv's soul.
The childlike smile brightened Rostóv's face.
Natásha said that Rostóv is quite a man.
Natásha said that she is glad Rostóv is her brother.
Natásha touched Rostóv's mustache.
Natásha wanted to know what men are like.
Rostóv asked why Sónya ran away.
Natásha asked how Rostóv would speak to Sónya, whether using thou or you.
Natásha told Rostóv to call Sónya "you".
Natásha told Rostóv she would tell him all about it later.
Natásha told Rostóv she would tell him now.
Natásha said Sónya is her dearest friend.
Natásha said she burned her arm for Sónya's sake.
Natásha told Rostóv to look here.
Natásha pulled up her muslin sleeve.
Natásha showed Rostóv a red scar on her arm.
The scar was on Natásha's long, slender, delicate arm.
The scar was high above the elbow.
The scar was on the part of the arm covered even by a ball dress.
Natásha burned her arm to prove love for Sónya.
Natásha heated a ruler in the fire.
Natásha pressed the heated ruler on her arm.
Rostóv sat on the sofa with little cushions on its arms.
The sofa was in what used to be his old schoolroom.
Rostóv looked into Natásha's wildly bright eyes.
Rostóv re-entered the world of home and childhood.
The world of home and childhood had no meaning for anyone else.
The world of home and childhood gave Rostóv some of the best joys of his life.
The burning of an arm with a ruler as proof of love did not seem senseless to Rostóv.
Rostóv understood the burning of an arm with a ruler.
Rostóv was not surprised at the burning of an arm with a ruler.
Rostóv asked if that was all.
Natásha said they are such friends.
Natásha said all that ruler business was just nonsense.
Natásha said they are friends forever.
Natásha said that if she loves anyone, she loves them for life.
Natásha said she does not understand that, she forgets quickly.
Natásha asked what then.
Natásha said she loves Rostóv and he likes that.
Natásha flushed.
Natásha asked why Rostóv remembered before he went away.
Natásha said Sónya says Rostóv should forget all that.
Natásha quoted Sónya saying 'I shall love him always, but let him be free.'
Natásha asked if that was lovely and noble.
Natásha asked if that was very noble.
Rostóv became thoughtful.
Rostóv said he never goes back on his word.
Rostóv said Sónya is so charming that only a fool would renounce such happiness.
Natásha cried "No, no!".
Natásha said she and Sónya have already talked it over.
Natásha said they knew Rostóv would say so.
Natásha said it won't do because if Rostóv says that, it will seem as if Sónya had not meant it seriously.
Natásha said it makes it as if Rostóv were marrying Sónya because he must.
Natásha said that wouldn't do at all.
Rostóv saw that the decision had been well considered by Natásha and Sónya.
Sónya had struck Rostóv by her beauty on the preceding day.
Today, when Rostóv caught a glimpse of Sónya, she seemed more lovely.
Sónya was a charming girl of sixteen.
Sónya was evidently passionately in love with Rostóv.
Rostóv did not doubt that Sónya was passionately in love with him.
Rostóv wondered why he should not love Sónya now.
Rostóv wondered why he should not marry Sónya now.
Rostóv thought there were many other pleasures and interests before him.
Rostóv thought that they had taken a wise decision.
Rostóv thought he must remain free.
